awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Explorations in Quantum Gravity: Cosmological and Black Hole Spacetimes
awd_abstract_narration:
In Einstein's theory of general relativity classical spacetime ends at the singularities. Examples include the Big Bang singularity in cosmological models and the central singularity of the black hole spacetimes. At these events the spacetime curvature and tidal forces become infinite. Classical evolution stops. It has been hoped that quantum gravitational effects will provide insights on resolution of this fundamental problem. This Faculty Early CAREER award supports research towards answering various questions related to quantum gravity and resolution of singularities in cosmological and black hole spacetimes. The research carried out in this project will use techniques of loop quantum gravity. A primary objective will be to establish generic properties of quantum spacetime in presence of anisotropies and inhomogenities, and extract reliable phenomenological and observational predictions. The educational and outreach objectives of this project are designed to address a wide audience. The project aims to enhance the scientific enrichment of K-12 students via a public lecture series and science exhibitions and demonstrations. Active engagement techniques will be used to revamp undergraduate and graduate courses. Undergraduate and graduate students will also receive training through research activities.

Detailed implications of the singularity resolution on the physics in different models will be explored. The project aims to significantly broaden and advance our current understanding of the physics of quantum gravity. Research explorations will include (i) systematically investigating the quantization and resulting physics of different spacetimes including anisotropies, inhomogenities in Gowdy models and Schwarzschild black holes, (ii) extracting phenomenological implications by analyzing effects of quantum gravity on cosmological perturbations, and (iii) addressing fundamental issues in quantum cosmology using consistent histories approach. Numerical techniques developed in this project will also lead to fresh insights on results in the classical gravity, such as on the structure of spacetime near classical singularities.

por.por_cntn:
Various fundamental questions in theoretical physics concern with the origin of our Universe: What was there before the Big Bang predicted by Einstein's theory of General Relativity? Was there us Universe like ours or something else? How did classcial spacetime and its laws emerged? Similarly, there are fundamental questions on the end state of gravitational collapse: What lies beyond the black hole singularities? The research in this project focussed on some of these important questions from the perspective of loop quantum gravity -- an approach to marry quantum mechanics with general relativity. 

In the cousre of this project several explorations were carried out on fundamental questions such as above and various results were obtained. The main result was to show that when loop quantum gravity effects are considered the big bang singulairty is generically resolved by a big bounce. This was confirmed by developing state-of-the-art numerical schemes using supercomputers and various analytical and phenomenological investigations. In particular, resolution of cosmological singularities was confirmed in various isotropic and anisotropic cosmological models establishing robustness of big bounce predicted by lop quantum gravity. These resuts were extended to black hole spacetimes. Phenomenological implications for inflation and its alternatives were explroed.

A key question is how do we test such a theory? For that cosmic microwave background (CMB) observations are extremely valuable. Explorations on robustness of predictions from quantum gravity on CMB were made which show that future data would be helpful in restricting at least some approaches. Distinct signatures in CMB were evaluated for different approaches in loop quantum cosmology.

Two postdocs, two graduate students, along with two under-graduate students were trained on this project. They learned a variety of analytical and numerical techniques. 

On the public outreach, a Saturday Science public lecture series showcasing the best of scientific research from different fields wa run successfully for the general public of Baton Rouge area. Several talks were given in public schools.

In sumamry, research in this project opened various avenues to explore consequences of loop quantum gravity in cosmological and back hole spacetimes. All goals of the project were completed successfully.
